title: 109_hr3108
content:
The "Religious Freedom and Respect in the Armed Forces Commission Act" establishes a commission to promote religious freedom and respect in the armed forces. Religious freedom is defined as the freedom to choose, express, and exercise one's religious beliefs without coercion. The Commission is tasked with duties and powers related to ensuring religious freedom and respect in the armed forces. The Commission established by the "Religious Freedom and Respect in the Armed Forces Commission Act" is responsible for reviewing religious freedom, respect, and tolerance for spiritual diversity in the Armed Forces. This includes examining issues, assessing policies for religious exercise accommodation, reviewing relevant reports, and considering recommendations. The Commission established by the "Religious Freedom and Respect in the Armed Forces Commission Act" reviews religious freedom, respect, and tolerance for spiritual diversity in the Armed Forces. This includes clarifying guidelines, enhancing accommodation, and promoting respect for diverse spiritual values through hearings and evidence gathering. The Commission established by the "Religious Freedom and Respect in the Armed Forces Commission Act" has the authority to issue subpoenas, obtain official data from government agencies, and enter into contracts for services and reports to assist in carrying out its duties. SEC. 5. MEMBERSHIP. The Commission shall consist of 12 members with expertise in constitution, church-state relations, pastoral care, or professional development in the Armed Forces. Members will be appointed by the President, Speaker of the House, House minority leader, Senate majority leader, and Senate minority leader. The Commission, consisting of 12 members with expertise in various fields, will be appointed within 30 days of the Act's enactment. The President will designate one member as Chairman. Meetings will be held monthly, with a quorum of seven members. Members will serve without pay but receive travel expenses. The Commission may employ an executive secretary and necessary staff. Each member serves for the life of the Commission, with vacancies filled promptly. SEC. 6. REPORT.

Within 6 months of enactment, the Commission must report findings on religious freedom and tolerance in the Armed Forces, with recommendations to clarify and protect these rights. Recommendations on promoting tolerance for all spiritual values are also required.

SEC. 7. TERMINATION OF THE COMMISSION.

The Commission ends 60 days after submitting the report.

SEC. 8. FUNDING. Funds for the Commission will come from the Department of Defense appropriations.
